awd_titl_txt: Scaling Up Success: Using MATE's ROV Competitions to Build a Collaborative Learning Community that Fuels the Ocean STEM Workforce Pipeline
awd_abstract_narration:
The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center at the Monterey Community College in collaboration with Washington State University is engaging in a scale-up study of the remote operated vehicle (ROV) program to new audiences of middle and high school students and teachers. Using a train the trainers approach, the MATE ROV project is conducting at least 45 regional professional development workshops in 15 regions for a total of 500 teachers. Scaling-up the project also includes the development of regional teacher leaders who have the resources developed from previous funding and the support from MATE through materials, administrative processes, and professional development to expand the implementation of the MATE ROV competitions. The project outcomes include increased student interest in STEM and STEM careers as well as increasing their knowledge of STEM content and how engineering and science work together to solve real-world problems. Additional outcomes include increasing parental involvement to support and encourage students to continue with STEM studies and careers and the implementation of professional development, instructional resources and mentoring to increase teacher capacity to engage students in the MATE ROV competitions.

The project is expanding the focus of the MATE ROV from an after school program to connect the robotics focus of the program to the Next Generation Science Standards and create a series of curricula experiences across the middle grades complete with instructional videos. An online resource for parents is one mechanism that the project is developing to support parental involvement, and the structuring of regional parental advisory boards is a second. The project is conducting a longitudinal study of the students who participate in the MATE ROV competitions. The project is connecting the MATE ROV AlumniWeb to the National Student Clearinghouse to track students from the secondary experiences with the program into their college majors and matriculation. The project is also studying the ways that the variation of the MATE ROV professional development is evident throughout the 15 regional hubs of the project to provide a better understanding of how a technology-rich program moves to scale.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center was established as an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Center of Excellence with funding from the National Science Foundation in 1997.  Scaling up Success: Using MATE’s ROV Competitions to Build a Collaborative Learning Community that Fuels the Ocean STEM Workforce Pipeline, expanded on the best practices that MATE Center PIs identified, based on evaluation data and regional reporting, as most effective in reaching, engaging, and supporting student and teacher participation in STEM.  The project’s overarching goal was to encourage multi-year student participation in the MATE ROV Competition in an effort to deepen student interest and learning and reinforce pathways leading to the STEM workforce.  It was guided by the hypothesis that for each year a student participates in engineering design challenges such as the MATE ROV competition, their likelihood of going to college increases, their likelihood of declaring a STEM major increases, and their likelihood of entering the STEM workforce increases.  The following four goals provided the foundation for the project:

1)      Increase middle and high school students’ interest in STEM and STEM careers as well as their knowledge of STEM and understanding of how science and engineering work together to solve real-world problems.

2)      Provide teachers with professional development, instructional resources, and mentors to support and sustain the delivery of STEM learning experiences and career information.

3)      Increase parental involvement in order to support and encourage students to pursue STEM education and careers.

4)      Track students longitudinally to document how participation impacts their education and career path.

Over the lifetime of this award the project has:

  • Added a beginner/intermediate level to the progression of competition classes to help bridge the gap and support students’ advancement to the next level as they build upon their knowledge and skills and gain confidence in their abilities. 
  • Developed a progression of four ROV kits that complement the competition classes and offered them through the SeaMATE online store (https://seamate.org/) to remove barriers to participation, increase access, and help educators and students get started with building ROVs. 
  • Developed four building guides that align with each ROV kit, include a wealth of instructional resources (from how-to videos to narrated PowerPoint presentations), and are aligned with national (e.g., Next Generation Science Standards) and global (e.g., International Society for Technology in Education) standards.
  • Created https://materovcompetition.org/ and https://educate.materovcompetition.org/, a compendium of educational resources that includes the four ROV kit building guides.
  • Offered six in-person, week-long professional development workshops to 112 participants that included middle and high school teachers, informal educators, and MATE regional competition coordinators.
  • Offered 137 regional professional development workshops, 1,027 regional student skill-building workshops, pool practice days, and engineering review opportunities, and 453 “student-teacher” workshop experiences to a total of 2,721 formal and informal educators and more than 36,000 K-12 students.
  • Engaged an educational researcher and dozens of working professionals to develop a set of competition rubrics with exceptional inter-rater reliability that align with the technical and employability skills that are most in demand in the workplace.
  • Documented inspirational stories of students participating in the annual MATE World Championship where the students described the impact that the competition has had on their education and career choices. These videos are available on the MATE Vimeo Channel (https://vimeo.com/user14545135).
  • Between the MATE Center, its regional partners, and ROV competition participants, published well over 500 abstracts, journal papers, newspaper articles, websites, television news stories, and other publications that featured project activities and presented project information at more than 200 conferences, meetings, and community events.
  • Each year administered post-competition surveys to students, instructors/mentors, working professionals serving as judges and volunteers, and parents to collect feedback on program impact and inform future improvements.  The results of these surveys are available at https://www.marinetech.org/itest.
  • Administered two surveys of competition “alumni” and completed two data matches with the National Student Clearinghouse (NSC) to answer the following questions: “Where are they now?” and, “To what extent did their involvement with MATE influence their trajectory?”
    • The second alumni survey was administered in January 2020; results (N=634) demonstrate long-term impact:
      • 88% of college degrees (N=390) were STEM degrees
      • 83% of college students (N=305) were STEM majors
      • 77% of employed alumni (N=467) had a STEM-related job
      • 72% (N=634) credit the program with influencing their education/career
      • The program played a role in attaining college admittance (38%), employment (37%), internships (36%), scholarships (22%), and awards (19%)
  • The most recent NSC effort took place in the spring 2020.  A total of 6,358 former participants were identified for matching; 69% (or 4,410) were found in the NSC database. Of the 3,185 with a major of study in the database, 69% were enrolled in a STEM major; 73% of the 2,309 degrees were awarded in STEM disciplines.

Last Modified: 12/27/2021
Modified by: Jill M Zande

Images (1 of )
  • ITEST funds enabled this science teacher at Bolsa Knolls Middle School, which sits amongst the agriculture fields of Salinas, CA, to introduce ROV design and building to his students and field an all-female team of students to participate in the MATE Monterey Regional ROV Competition.
    MATE
    Creative Commons
    Jill M Zande
    All-Female ROV Team from Salinas, CA
  • A MATE team of high school students who got their start in middle school with ITEST funding showing off their underwater robot to Bill Nye, The Science Guy, at the 2016 White House Science Fair.
    Jill Zande @ MATE
    Creative Commons
    Jill M Zande
    MATE Team @ the 2016 White House Science Fair
  • With the support of ITEST funding, these students participated in the MATE Monterey Bay Regional ROV Competition for the first time in 2016. Here they are delivering their engineering presentation to two judges who are working professional engineers.
    MATE
    Creative Commons
    Jill M Zande
    First-time MATE competitors
  • With the support of ITEST funding, these students participated in the MATE Monterey Bay Regional ROV Competition for the first time in 2016. Here they are delivering their engineering presentation to two judges who are working professional engineers.
    MATE
    Creative Commons
    Jill M Zande
    First-time MATE competitors
  • ITEST funding supported professional development workshops for teachers as well as for MATE Regional Competition Coordinators, seen here building their soldering skills. Empowering coordinators with these skills allowed them to pass on their knowledge and training to teachers in their regions.
    MATE
    Creative Commons
    Jill M Zande
    Underwater Robotics Professional Development Workshop
  • ITEST supported the development of the "NAVIGATOR" class, which became part of MATE's progression of competition classes that encourage and allow students to stay engaged and advance to the next level as they build upon their knowledge, skills, and confidence in designing and building ROVs.
    MATE
    Creative Commons
    Jill M Zande
    ROV Team Members Prepare to Launch Their ROV
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Marine Advanced Technology Education (MATE) Center was established as an Advanced Technological Education (ATE) Center of Excellence with funding from the National Science Foundation in 1997.  Scaling up Success: Using MATE’s ROV Competitions to Build a Collaborative Learning Community that Fuels the Ocean STEM Workforce Pipeline, expanded on the best practices that MATE Center PIs identified, based on evaluation data and regional reporting, as most effective in reaching, engaging, and supporting student and teacher participation in STEM.  The project’s overarching goal was to encourage multi-year student participation in the MATE ROV Competition in an effort to deepen student interest and learning and reinforce pathways leading to the STEM workforce.  It was guided by the hypothesis that for each year a student participates in engineering design challenges such as the MATE ROV competition, their likelihood of going to college increases, their likelihood of declaring a STEM major increases, and their likelihood of entering the STEM workforce increases.  The following four goals provided the foundation for the project:

1)      Increase middle and high school students’ interest in STEM and STEM careers as well as their knowledge of STEM and understanding of how science and engineering work together to solve real-world problems.

2)      Provide teachers with professional development, instructional resources, and mentors to support and sustain the delivery of STEM learning experiences and career information.

3)      Increase parental involvement in order to support and encourage students to pursue STEM education and careers.

4)      Track students longitudinally to document how participation impacts their education and career path.

Over the lifetime of this award the project has:

Added a beginner/intermediate level to the progression of competition classes to help bridge the gap and support students’ advancement to the next level as they build upon their knowledge and skills and gain confidence in their abilities.  
Developed a progression of four ROV kits that complement the competition classes and offered them through the SeaMATE online store (https://seamate.org/) to remove barriers to participation, increase access, and help educators and students get started with building ROVs.  
Developed four building guides that align with each ROV kit, include a wealth of instructional resources (from how-to videos to narrated PowerPoint presentations), and are aligned with national (e.g., Next Generation Science Standards) and global (e.g., International Society for Technology in Education) standards.
Created https://materovcompetition.org/ and https://educate.materovcompetition.org/, a compendium of educational resources that includes the four ROV kit building guides.
Offered six in-person, week-long professional development workshops to 112 participants that included middle and high school teachers, informal educators, and MATE regional competition coordinators.
Offered 137 regional professional development workshops, 1,027 regional student skill-building workshops, pool practice days, and engineering review opportunities, and 453 "student-teacher" workshop experiences to a total of 2,721 formal and informal educators and more than 36,000 K-12 students.
Engaged an educational researcher and dozens of working professionals to develop a set of competition rubrics with exceptional inter-rater reliability that align with the technical and employability skills that are most in demand in the workplace.
Documented inspirational stories of students participating in the annual MATE World Championship where the students described the impact that the competition has had on their education and career choices. These videos are available on the MATE Vimeo Channel (https://vimeo.com/user14545135). 
Between the MATE Center, its regional partners, and ROV competition participants, published well over 500 abstracts, journal papers, newspaper articles, websites, television news stories, and other publications that featured project activities and presented project information at more than 200 conferences, meetings, and community events.
Each year administered post-competition surveys to students, instructors/mentors, working professionals serving as judges and volunteers, and parents to collect feedback on program impact and inform future improvements.  The results of these surveys are available at https://www.marinetech.org/itest. 
Administered two surveys of competition "alumni" and completed two data matches with the National Student Clearinghouse (NSC) to answer the following questions: "Where are they now?" and, "To what extent did their involvement with MATE influence their trajectory?"  

The second alumni survey was administered in January 2020; results (N=634) demonstrate long-term impact: 

88% of college degrees (N=390) were STEM degrees
83% of college students (N=305) were STEM majors
77% of employed alumni (N=467) had a STEM-related job
72% (N=634) credit the program with influencing their education/career
The program played a role in attaining college admittance (38%), employment (37%), internships (36%), scholarships (22%), and awards (19%)




The most recent NSC effort took place in the spring 2020.  A total of 6,358 former participants were identified for matching; 69% (or 4,410) were found in the NSC database. Of the 3,185 with a major of study in the database, 69% were enrolled in a STEM major; 73% of the 2,309 degrees were awarded in STEM disciplines.
